page.title: 06Pendomer: Farming 2
page.content: Nearly all the land is ploughed every few years, and either sown with grass or used for growing wheat (for sale) or barley (for feeding stock). On the cornbrash soils the grain crops are particularly important. There is little permanent pasture and virtually no unimproved grassland. Both silage and hay are made, and the larger farms have their own dairies, grain stores, and combines, while the smaller farms may share these. On several farms, and on some other parcels of land which are no longer working farms, a few horses are kept. Hunting is a popular pursuit in the area - viewed with predictably mixed feelings by farmers! Some of them enjoy hunting; others regard it as a nuisance, apt to damage hedges and drive foxes into the farm- yards and chicken runs. It does little to control the foxes.
